9.text: Hi I'm Oli Spleen and I am originally from Hastings

12.text: which is an interesting & difficult place to grow up,

17.text: Since childhood I always felt closer to women than men

21.text: I remember from the first day

23.text: at primary school, I asked my mother

25.text: why am I not a girl?

26.text: because I didn't feel like I was able to

28.text: act in the way that the other boys did at school

33.text: I also would wear make up and women's clothes

36.text: from as young as I could remember, mostly at my grandma's house

41.text: and this is one of the earliest pictures of me.

45.text: I think my alter ego is called Jean Farnfield, at the time. She was a gardening presenter.

51.text: Men to me, at that age, seemed very disapproving authoritarian figures

55.text: When women, my mother, my sister, my grandmother and her friends

59.text: I was very close to them.

62.text: and they seemed warm and caring

64.text: and the thought of turning into a man

66.text: was something that horrified me at that age.

72.text: But in the same time I was made to feel that if I'd express myself in a feminine way

76.text: it would be seen at something very

81.text: Luckily I've lived into a time where gay and trans people  are a part of our social vocabulary

87.text: we have a far better understand of these things

90.text: As I became a teenager, my love of alternative music led me to

97.text: and androgony within the music world

101.text: and I didn't have present myself in the way society expected

112.text: Though, this time I resigned myself to the fact I was male

116.text: I realised I could have an impact on those around me by challenging notions of masculinity

123.text: And what it is to be male rather than challenging or changing my physical gender

131.text: I might have transitioned if I had have confronted these things before

135.text: puberty and grew up in more enlightened times but it wasn't something I felt I could have talked to my parents about

141.text: I don't believe in the notion of opposite sex

144.text: I think we're all more female and male than we let on

149.text: And to a considerable degree it's social conditioning

152.text: which leads us to present ourselves in a more masculine

157.text: To me ideas of mascuinity and feminity are largely social constructs

163.text: We are all female in the womb in our earliest stages of developement

168.text: I don't know if there are some colors that resonate with people, but maybe I am genderqueer

173.text: but one thing I am not very tolerant of is definitions, so

177.text: therefore I avoid that one as well as the gender one

186.text: (singing) You motherf*ckers need someone to hate

188.text: They've got a burden and you’re feeling its weight

191.text: ‘Cause you don’t fit into their narrow-mind’s space

193.text: You've been kicked down and spat in the face

195.text: Do they insult you, do they call you a fag

197.text: Use you as a human punching bag

199.text:
Lash out at you because they’re scared of 
themselves

202.text: It’s always easier to hate someone else
